Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 I. INTRODUCTION  
 
The Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB ”) respectfully submits this initial brief (“CUB 
Initial Brief”) to provide recommendations to the Administrative Law Judge (“ALJ”) and the Minnesota 
Public Utilities Commission (the “Commission”) regarding the  July 19, 2024 petition (the “Petition”)  by 
ALLETE, owner of Minnesota Power1 (“ALLETE ” or the “Company”) . ALLETE seeks approval of a 
proposed transaction through which the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board ( “CPP” or “CPP 
Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP” , collectively with CPP Investments, the 
“Partners” ) would acquire 100% of the outstanding shares of ALLETE, Inc . (the “Proposed Acquisition.”) 
CUB is a n independent, Minnesota -based nonprofit organization.  CUB’s role in this proceeding is to 
advocate  for residential consumers’ interests by scrutinizing the Petition and assessing potential risks 
and benefits that arise from it.  
The Company claims the Proposed  Acquisition is “consistent with the public interest” -
primarily because it provides improved access to capital, which the Company will need to comply with Minnesota’s carbon reduction policies. The Company also suggests that it, and its customers, will 
benefit from the Partners’ expertise in renewable energy projects. However, a number of 
inconsistencies on the record call into question the value of these purported benefits. For example, 
though the Company claims in the Petit ion it will not be able to raise sufficient capital via public 
markets, its last two Annual Reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission suggest the 
Company is “well positioned to meet [its] financing needs due to adequate operating cash flows , 
available additional working capital and access to capital markets.”
2 Moreover, though the Company 
claims it had its customers’ interests in mind when identifying the Partners as entities that share the 
Company’s values, the Company rejected the Partners’ first two offers in order to negotiate a higher acquisition premium. Finally, though the Partners are experienced institutional investors, the Partners 
send mixed signals about how they intend to utilize that expertise to influence the Company’s 
decisions—on one hand, they suggest that Minnesota Power’s day -to-day operation s will continue to 
be managed by existing Minnesota Power staff; on the other hand, the Partners have negotiated a

Meanwhile, several parties have identified potential risks likely to outweigh the potential 
benefits. First, the Partners are paying a considerable, 19 to 20 percent acquisition premium to acquire 
ALLETE, and they will have to recover at least that amount to earn a return on their investment. It seems likely that the Partners will push the Company to grow Minnesota Power’s rate base and/or increase rates more than may be necessary to generate that return. Further , though the  Company  
claims  in this docket th at it need s improved access capital to support “Minnesota Power’s continued 
advancement toward complying with Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free Standard,”  the Company ’s 
recently and separately filed integrated resource plan reveals plans to  “add approximately 1,000 
megawatts of natural gas capacity .”
3 Finally, due to the Partners’ size and scope of investments, 
approval of the Proposed  Acquisition would introduce considerable conflicts of interest that amplify 
the risk that the Partners will use their influence and control over ALLETE to benefit  affiliated interests 
or other companies held in its portfolio, potentially to the detriment of Minnesota Power customers.  
On balance, the risks of potential harm arising from the Proposed  Acquisition outweigh its 
potential benefits. Therefore, the Proposed  Acquisition is not consistent with the public interest, and 
the Commission should deny its approval.  
 
II. LEGAL STANDARD  
 
A. The Petitioners have the burden of proof to s how the Proposed Acquisition  is 
consistent with the p ublic interest. 
 
Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 prohibits  public utilities  from selling “ an operating unit or system 
in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000 [. . .] without first being authorized so to 
do by the commission. ”  The law directs the Commission to approve the  sale only if  it finds it is 
“consistent with the public interest [.]” As the entities seeking the Commission’s approval of the 
Proposed Acquisition, the Petitioners have the burden of proof to demonstrate the Proposed Acquisition is consistent with the Public Interest.   
 
3 See Ex. Sierra Club -1102 (Corrected Lane Surrebuttal) at  Attachment CLS -1 (eDocket No. 20254- 217233- 02).

Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 The Petitioners suggest that Minn. Stat. § 216 B.50 “does not require an affirmative finding of 
public benefit but requires only a finding that the transaction is compatible with the public interest.”4 
In support of this assertion, they cite a Commission order issued in November 1990.5 The Commission 
has also historically “used a balancing test to determine if an acquisition is ‘consistent with the public 
interest,’ weighing perceived detriments against benefits.”6 Notwithstanding the foregoing , there is no 
requirement for the current Commission to conform its review of the Proposed Acquisition to that of 
its predecessors—particularly  considering that Minnesota law and policy  surrounding electric services  
has changed considerably since 1990. For example, in 2007 the Minnesota Legislature passed the Next Generation Energy Act after finding “that continued growth in demand for energy will cause severe social and economic dislocations” and that “the protection of life, safety, and financial sec urity for 
citizens during an energy crisis is of paramount importance.”
7 2017  legislation created an energy 
policy goal of holding retail electricity rates for each customer class to be at least five present below 
the national average.8 In 2010, the Legislature acted again to reframe utilities’ annual spending goals 
as savings goals. And, finally, in 2023 the Legislature adopted the Carbon Free Standard that pushes 
Minnesota utilities to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2040.9 Acknowledgment  of these 
legislative developments—as well as the myriad other developments that have evolved in Commission 
proceedings over the past 35 years—inform and add to what it means to be “consistent with the public 
interest” today.  
 
B. If the Petitioners seek a pproval of the Proposed Acquisition to m eet Minnesota’s 
Carbon Free Standard, then the Commission must implement that Standard in 
a way that m aximizes public benefits. 
 
Throughout their filings in this docket, the Petitioners suggest that approving the Proposed 
Acquisition is consistent with the public interest because the Company requires improved access to capital  to comply with Minnesota’s Carbon Free Standard ( Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691  Subd. 2g).

MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 Standard requires Minnesota electric utilities to “generate or procure sufficient electricity generated 
from a carbon -free energy technology to provide the electric utility's retail customers in Minnesota, 
or the retail customers of a distribution utility to which the electric utility provide s wholesale electric 
service, so that the electric utility generates or procures an amount of electricity from carbon- free 
energy technologies that is equivalent to at least the following standard percentages of the electric 
utility's total retail electric  sales to retail customers in Minnesota by the end of the year indicated:  
(1) 2030  80 percent for public utilities; 60 percent for  
other electric utilities  
(2) 2035  90 percent for all electric utilities  
(3) 2040  100 percent for all electric utilities.” 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 Subd. 2b also directs the Comm ission to “modify or delay the 
implementation [of the above standard] in whole or in part, if the commission determines that 
modifying or delaying the standard obligation is in the public interest.” When evaluating a request to 
modify or delay implementation of a standard, the Commission must consider (among other factors) 
“the impact of implementing the standard on its customers’ utility costs, including the economic and 
competitive  pressure on the utility’s customers.”   
Also importantly, the 2023 legislation establishing the Carbon Free Standard affirmatively 
requires  the Commission to “maximize net benefits” to Minnesotans when implementing it:  
 
The commission shall take all reasonable actions within the commission's statutory authority 
to ensure this section [§ 216B.1691] is implemented in a manner that maximizes net benefits 
to all Minnesota citizens.11 
 
It is inconsistent for the Petitioner’s, on one hand, to suggest Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 “does not 
require an affirmative finding of public benefit” and, on the other hand, justify the Proposed 
Acquisition as necessary to comply with legislation that require s the Commissio n, when implementing

Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 that legislation , to maximize public benefits. Because compliance with the Carbon Free Standard is 
foundational to the Petitioners’ request for approval, the requirements of Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 
Subd. 9(a) provide a good starting point for the Commission to sharpen what it means to be 
“consistent with the public interest” in this context. Of particular importance to CUB , the Commission 
should consider whether the Proposed Acquisition, if approved, would maximize:  “the provision of 
affordable electric service to Minnesotans, particularly to low -income consumers. ”12 At minimum, the 
Commission should consider whether potential harms to the public —including rate increases arising 
from or amplified by the Proposed Acquisition— outweigh its potential benefits. To balance potential 
benefits against potential risks, the Commission should consider whether the ”commitments” the 
Company and Partners offer to address Parties‘ concerns represent new , proactive actions that 
counter new  risks and potential harms arising from the transaction, or whether they merely articulate 
status quo actions the Commission would expect to continue whether or not the Proposed Acquisition 
is approve d. 
 
III. ARGUMENT  
 
If the Proposed Acquisition is approved, ALLETE will transition from a publicly traded company 
with its ownership shared by hundreds or thousands of unrelated shareholders to a private company owned by two entities, GIP and CPP Investments, who act in part nership. At a high level, the primary 
purported benefit of this transition would be to allow ALLLETE improved access to capital from the 
Partners —specifically to fund the Company’s five -year capital plan. The Petition also cite s the Partners’ 
experience wi th infrastructure investments as a potential benefit. For the reasons discussed below, 
the value of both benefits is unclear and/or overstated.  
Meanwhile, we are concerned that the Partners’ efforts to recoup their investment will cause 
or exasperate rate increases;  allow the Partners  excessive influence and control over  the governance 
of ALLETE and Minnesota Power; introduce complex affiliated interest concerns; reduce transparency; 
and generally put undue pressure on the Commission, government agencies, and intervenors to 
mitigate new risk of consumer harm in the future . The Company’s and Partners’ offered commitments 
and affirmations do little t o assuage these concerns.

standards[.]”)

A. Potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
Proposed Acquisition  are either unclear or overstated.  
 
The Company asserts two potential benefits that arise from the Proposed Acquisition : 
improved access to capital and access to the Partners’ experience in renewable infrastructure 
investments. Evidence introduced by intervenors’ witnesses raises considerable doubt about the weight of both purported benefits.  
 
i. Witness Taran’s testimony is inconsistent with Annual Reports filed with the 
Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC”).  
 
Company witness, Joshua D. Taran, testifies that ALLETE needs to raise approximately $1 
billion of external equity over the next five years alone to fund the over $4 billion in planned capital 
expenditures, in addition to significant new debt issuances and refinancing.13  Witness Taran further 
testifies that “[b]ecause ALLETE’s operations do not generate sufficient cash flow to fund its capital needs, the Company would not be able to make the necessary investments to meet the State’s Carbon 
Free Standard without external c apital” and that “it is highly likely that ALLETE would have difficulty 
raising” that external capital if ALLETE remains publicly traded.
14  After Intervenors filed direct 
testimony expressing concerns about the Proposed Acquisition, the Partner’s indicated a 
“commitment”  to fund the Company’s 5 -year investment plan found in the Company’s 2024 Annual 
Report ( Form 10 -K) filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (“SEC”).15  
In exchange for being able to raise capital via public markets, ALLETE (as a public company) is 
subject to stringent reporting and disclosure requirements under the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. Specifically, public companies must file periodic, quarterly, and annual reports with the SEC  
providing detailed information about the company’s financial health and the company’s exposure to 
potential risks that could affect the value of an investment in that company . Failure to transparently 
disclose such r isks exposes a company and its officers and directors to serious potential liability , as 
does otherwise making materially false or misleading statements.

public company, it regularly files reports with the SEC. Those Reports are reviewed, approved and

iii. The Partners’ “commitment” to support the Company’s capital needs is 
unenforceable.  
 
In discovery, CUB posed the following question to the Petitioners: “ For all benefits that you 
assert will come from this transaction, explain why those benefits would not be available without the 
transaction. ” In response, the Company said, in part:  
 
The primary benefit of the transaction, as stated in the July 19, 2024 Petition, is that the

vii. Approval of the Proposed Acquisition may have other unintended, avoidable

The Company’s and Partners’ Joint Witness, John Quackenbush, cites the acquisition of the

of a regulated utility company is  approved without careful consideration of potential consequences .  
CUB Witness Jester, a Michigan -based consultant, has monitored or participated in many 
Michigan Public Service Commission proceedings involving UPPCO, including the first rate case UPPCO filed after it was acquired by private infrastructure investors. Witness Jester describes some of the 
consequences that arose for UPPCO and its customers after it was acquired by a private infrastructure investor:  
 
• UPPCO requested a large increase in its return on common equity;  
• UPPCO requested substantial increases in expenses to recover increases in pension costs not adequately disclosed or discussed in the acquisition docket;  
• UPPCO proposed a large increase to distribution system maintenance expenses after reducing maintenance investments while approval of the acquisition was pending;  
• UPPCO was slow to terminate an above -market power purchase agreement (“PPA”) with an 
affiliated entity;

169 See generally, Ex. ECC- 700 ( Shardlow Surrebuttal ) (eDocket No. 20253- 21679701). 
PUBLIC –HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATIO N REDACTED  
 
35 
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 is approved, we will continue to work with the Company and ECC to support its continuation to help 
serve the needs of low- income Minnesota Power customers. However , several issues with this 
commitment reveal it s benefits are limited. 
First, the CARE program is funded by ratepayers, not shareholders.170 It was created  in 2011 
after the Commission ordered Minnesota Power to develop a low- income affordability program , and 
the Commission has  continuously approved funding for the program in every year since then through 
its review of annual reports .171 Because it is a ratepayer -funded program that  is subject to the 
Commission’s ongoing review, the commitment to not reduce the CARE budget is simply a commitment to not request the Commission’s approval to lower the budge t—a request unlikely to be 
approved given the popularity of and need for the program . Further, because other ratepayers fund 
the program through a surcharge added to their bills , the commitment to not reduce the CARE budget 
is not a new benefit the Company or Partners offer in support of the Proposed Acquisition —it is a 
commitment to continue charging the majority  of ratepayers to  fund a program utilized by some 
ratepayers .  
Second, If customer rates go up after the Proposed Acquisition is approved, more customers 
are likely to spend more than 3% of their annual income on their electric bills —creating more demand 
for an affordability discount program .
172 A commitment to maintain the CARE program’s existing 
budget and eligibility requirements, while good for current CARE participants, does not  help 
customers struggling to pay their bills  but that are ineligible for the CARE flat discount  or eligible but  
currently  unable to participate in the full -subscribed  affordability discount .173 
Finally, the Partners’ commitment to provide funding to pay down arrears, while helpful to 
some customers in the near -term, will not provide widespread, lasting protections. Witness Cady 
estimates the dollar value of this commitment to be approximately $3. 5 million— though she 
acknowledges that, technically, the dollar amount required to meet that commitment could be less.174 
Even if the Partners were to pay off the full amount of Minnesota Powers’ arrears (totaling around 
$4.3 million as of February 2025),175 that financial commitment would represent less than 0.1 percent 
of the value the Partners have committed to acquire ALLETE. Importantly, reducing current arrears to 
 
170 Hearing Transcript Vol . 1 at 188.  
171 Id. 
172 Hearing Transcript Vol. 3 at  759. 
173 Hearing Transcript Vol . 1 a5 189.  
174 Hearing Transcript Vol 1. at 194- 195.  
175 Hearing Transcript Vol. 1 at  195.  
PUBLIC –HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATIO N REDACTED  
 
36 
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 pre-COVID levels would not prevent customers from falling into arrears in the future if their rates 
dramatically increase.  
b. Union workforce  
 
CUB supports ALLETE’s ongoing employment of local workers and engagement with 
Minnesota’s labor unions. In that regard, we are pleased to see that IBEW Local 31 has successfully extended it s collective bargaining agreement with Minnesota Power through April 30, 2028.
176 
However, this benefit is not one that newly arises because of the Proposed Acquisition; it is a benefit 
that continues despite it. “The Company routinely contractually requires contractors and 
subcontractors to pay their workers prevailing wage as evidenced by local collective bargaining agreements and to ascertain local conditions, work rules, and union jurisdiction. The Company also  
seeks to deploy union labor wherever reasonably possible.”
177 The Commission , too, has recently 
included requirements supporting  use of  local labor in its orders. For example, when approving 
Minnesota Power’s last integrated resource plan, the Commission ordered Minnesota Power to “work[ ] with organized labor and other interested stakeholders to maximize . . . use of local labor for construction and permanent staffing[.]”
178 We expect Minnesota Power’s and the Commission’s 
support of local labor to continue regardless of whether the Proposed Acquisition is approved.  
 
D. Although FERC and the Wisconsin Public Service Commission have already approved 
the Proposed Acquisition, the Commission should heed warnings offered by the 
FERC Chairman  in concurring opinions . 
 For the Proposed Acquisition to successfully close, Minnesota Power must obtain certain  
shareholder and regulatory approvals. The Company has already obtained necessary approvals from ALLETE’s shareholders, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (“FERC”), and the Wisconsin Public 
Service Commission.
179 According to the Company, the  “only remaining state or federal regulatory 
approval required to close this transaction is that of the Commission in this docket.”180 
 
176 Ex. IBEW -802 (Keyes Surrebuttal) at 1 (eDocket No. 20253- 216812- 02) 
177 Ex. MP -27 (Cady Rebuttal) at 22- 23 (eDocket No. 20253- 216055- 03). 
178 In the Matter of Minnesota Power’s 20212035 Integrated Resource Plan , Order Approving Plan and Setting Additional 
Requirements, Docket No. E -015/RP- 21-33 (Jan. 9, 2023) at 13; see also  Minn. Stat 216I.05, subd. 11 (requiring the Commission, 
when determining whether to issue a site permit for a large energy infrastructure facility, to evaluate the proposed facility ’s 
employment and economic impacts, including the quantity, quality, and compensation level of construction and permanent 
jobs.)  
179 Ex. MP -40 (Cady Surrebuttal) at 3. (eDocket No. 20253- 216810- 02) 
180 Id. 
PUBLIC –HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATIO N REDACTED  
 
37 
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 FERC approved the Proposed Acquisition without reviewing nearly the volume of evidence 
available to the Commission in this docket.181  Only three  intervenors —LPI, and Public Citizen and 
Private Equity Stakeholder Project filing jointly —filed substantive comments with FERC on the 
Proposed Acquisition, and they had just 60 days after the Company filed its June 19, 2024 application 
to prepare written  protests .182 The Company filed an answer to intervenors’ protests  on October 2, 
2024, and intervenors filed comments responding to that answer in early November 2024.183 This 
condensed review period did not allow for the rigorous discovery and analysis that informs the expert 
witness testimony and legal briefs filed with the Minnesota Commission in this proceeding.  Further , 
FERC clarified in its Order that “whether the Proposed Acquisition fulfills the respective state 
requirements for Minnesota Commission and Wisconsin Commission approval is a separate question 
from whether the Proposed Acquisition is consistent with the public interest under [the Federal Power 
Act (FPA)] section 203, and our findings under FPA section 203 do not affect those agencies’ evaluation 
of the Proposed Acquisition pursuant to their respective statutory authorities.”184  
In related FERC proceedings,  FERC Chairman Marc C. Christie issued warnings that should 
inform the Commission’s review of the Proposed Acquisition. Prior to approving the Proposed 
Acquisition in the order cited above , FERC approved BlackRock’s $12.5 billion acquisition of GIP.185 In 
a concurring opinion accompanying that approval, Chairman Christie  expressed concerns about the 
power “huge asset managers, like BlackRock” will wield when seeking to acquire interests in public utilities.
186 He then  specifically called on “all utility regulators” to heed their responsibility “to make 
sure that such money is not being needlessly extracted from [energy] consumers’ pockets through 
exercises of market power or other forms of rent -seeking.”187 Chairman Christie issued a similar 
warning in a concurring opinion accompan ying another recent  FERC order approving  the extension of 
BlackRock’s “blanket authorization ” to acquire voting securities of any public utilit y: 
 
 
181 Order Authorizing Disposition of Jurisdictional Facilities and Acquisition of Securities, Docket No. EC24 -105-000 (Dec. 19, 2024),  p. 
13, available at https://www.ferc.gov/media/e -14-ec24- 105- 000.  
182 Id. at 22.  
183 Id. at 13.  
184 Id. at 21 -22. 
185 Order Authorizing Disposition of Jurisdictional Facilities and Acquisition of Securities re Global Infrastructure Management,  LLC et 
al. FERC Docket EC24 -58 (Sept. 6, 2024) , available at https://elibrary.ferc.gov/eLibrary/filelist?accession number=20240906-
3099&optimized=false .    
186 Order Authorizing Disposition of Jurisdictional Facilities and Acquisition of Securities, Docket No. EC24 -58-000 (Sept. 6, 2024), 
available at https://elibrary.ferc.gov/eLibrary/filelist?accession number=20240906- 3099&optimized=false . 
187 Id. at Christie Concurring opinion, p. 3.   
PUBLIC –HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATIO N REDACTED  
 
38 
Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, Initial Brief  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 I have expressed my concern in the past about the specter of a huge asset manager, such as 
BlackRock, using its substantial holdings to exert control over the operational decisions of a 
public utility.  Owning 20%, or even less than that, of a utility’s stock could well result in the 
exercise of substantial influence over a util ity. . . As I also have said before, a public utility has 
public service obligations; it is not just another company seeking to maximize returns to its shareholders.  Many have been granted monopoly franchises by state governments in return 
for serving the public within their territories.  One threat is that asset managers, like BlackRock, 
will use their ownership of competing assets to exert market power in wholesale energy, 
capacity, and ancillary services markets.
188 
 Chairman Christie issues this warning about large asset managers “owning 20%, or even less” of a 
utility’s stock. If the Proposed Acquisition is approved, GIP (now wholly owned by BlackRock) will own 60 percent of ALLETE, and CPP will own the other 40 percent. The Minnesota Commission should heed 
Chairman Christie’s warning and should carefully review the robust record built in this proceeding to 
make its own decision under Minnesota Law as to whether the Proposed Acquisition is consistent with the Public Interest.  
 
IV. CONCLUSION  
 
On balance, the risks of potential harm arising from the Proposed Acquisition outweigh its 
potential benefits. Therefore, the Proposed Acquisition is not consistent with the public interest, and 
the Commission should deny its approval.  
 Dated: May  1, 202 5      Respectfully submitted,  
         
       /s/ Brian C. Edstrom

content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Brian Gustafson
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Public Comments for Docket E-015/PA-24-198
Date: Tuesday, April 29, 2025 3:35:04 PM
You don't often get email from brian@onsitesolutionsgroup.com. Learn why this is important
To Whom It May Concern,
I am writing on behalf of Onsite Solutions Group LLC to express our strong support for ALLETE
and their ongoing acquisition process.
As a small northern Minnesota business that has worked closely with ALLETE for several
years, we have consistently experienced their unwavering commitment to partnering with
local vendors and contributing positively to the regional economy. ALLETE has been
instrumental in helping businesses like ours grow and thrive, and their support goes farbeyond contractual obligations — they invest in relationships and in the long-term success of
their community.
In every interaction, the ALLETE team has demonstrated integrity, professionalism, and a deep
respect for collaborative, community-minded business practices. They treat their partners as
true stakeholders, fostering a spirit of cooperation that is rare and deeply appreciated.
We believe that the proposed acquisition — while a major change — will allow ALLETE to
expand its positive impact, not only maintaining its local focus but enhancing it throughgreater investment capacity and strategic alignment. We have full confidence that the company
will remain a strong and principled partner to the communities it serves, including local
businesses like ours.
Thank you for your time and consideration.
Sincerely,
Brian Gustafson
Owner - PresidentCell:  (218) 242-4945Brian@onsitesolutionsgroup.com
 
"Connecting  the people  with the purpose. "
www.onsitesolutionsgroup.com

Additional Info: Received Outside Comment Period Alice Madden
content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Alice Madden
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: 24-198 - Reject the private sale of one of Minnesota"s biggest utilities
Date: Monday, April 28, 2025 10:38:25 AM
Please reject the private sale of this utility to Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP)
and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP). 
GIP itself is owned by BlackRock, the world’s largest investment firm. As our consumer
advocate , Citizens Utility Board, notes:  BlackRock’s $11.5 trillion in assets under
management exceeds the GDP of every nation except the United States and China. Thoseincentives do not align
 with the public interest and will make it impossible to align
affordability and reliability with the legally embedded mandate BlackRock has to extractprofits, and the abundant evidence that BlackRock has stripped other areas of community life(housing in particular) of value and financial buffer for the wellbeing of the users (householdsand energy users in this case). Not only that but most of the shareholders would beinternational, not local or regional. Wealth then is not only extracted but exported. For what?
Please do not condone or allow this. sincerely, Alice Madden

image002.png
You don't often get email from pat.degrood@jamarcompany.us. Learn why this is important
To whom it may concern:
 We are writing to express our strong support for the proposed acquisition of Minnesota Power byALLETE.  The Jamar Company has had a long-standing and close relationship with Minnesota Power,and we have always found them to be an essential, positive force within our community. Minnesota Power has demonstrated a consistent commitment to responsible energy management,reliable service, and innovative solutions that have benefited both consumers and businesses alike.Their team are highly skilled professionals and are also active participants in local initiatives,charities, and economic development projects. It is our belief that the acquisition with ALLETE will only strengthen Minnesota Power’s ability toprovide value to our community and enhance local economic opportunities. This acquisition will givethem additional stability and will allow them to continue to lead the way in their industry. We haveevery confidence that Minnesota Power will continue its tradition of community partnership,sustainable practices, and service excellence as it moves forward. We lend our enthusiastic support to Minnesota Power and look forward to working together for manyyears to come. Sincerely, 
Pat deGrood

PUC Docket Number 24 -198 – Letter of Support for Minnesota Power  
April 23, 2025  
To the Public Utilities Commission,  
On behalf of the Hermantown Area Chamber of Commerce, we are writing to 
express our full support for the proposed acquisition of ALLETE and the resulting 
ownership structure of Minnesota Power.  
Minnesota Power has long been a respected and valued member of our Chamber 
and a key contributor to the vitality of our region. As a trusted utility and community 
partner, they have consistently demonstrated a strong commitment to responsible 
energy delive ry, local leadership, and long -term investment in the economic and 
environmental well -being of northeast Minnesota.  
We care deeply about the continued strength and stability of Minnesota Power —
not only for what they represent as an energy provider, but for the critical role they 
play in enabling growth and innovation across our business community. From 
infrastructure de velopment to workforce support, their impact is wide -reaching and 
essential.  
The assurances that Minnesota Power’s headquarters, leadership, regulatory 
oversight, values, and philanthropic efforts will remain intact provide confidence 
and continuity for the region. The key benefit of this acquisition —greater access to 
capital —posit ions the company to more effectively meet state -mandated carbon -
free goals and fund the infrastructure investments necessary to modernize our 
energy grid.  
This is not a departure from their mission, but a strategic move to strengthen it. In 
a time when many rural and regional areas face uncertainty in energy and 
economic development, Minnesota Power’s approach offers stability, growth, and 
a clear path forwa rd. 
We respectfully urge the Commission to approve this acquisition. Doing so will 
support a company that has consistently demonstrated its commitment to the 
Northland and that remains poised to lead our region into a carbon -free, 
economically vibrant future.  
Sincerely,  
 
Kim Parmeter  
President & CEO

Drar Judge Megan J. MchengiI hope that the acquisition of ALLETE by CPP and GIP will not go forward.DEGEIVEByAPR 17 2025My husband David and I attended the Monday evening, April 7, 2025 public hearing inDuluth regarding the acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment (CPP) andGlobal Infrastructure Partners (GIP), which is owned by BlackRock. We appreciated beingable to listen to statements from citizens on both sides of this acquisition and weappreciated your professionalism and courtesy to all of us present. We listened carefullyfrom seats near the front, took a few notes, and went home to discuss our own reactions.During the week after this hearing, before my written response, I read about both CPP andGIP/BlackRock and my areas of concern were even more heightened, particularly having todo with the latter.I noticed at the hearing that most of the persons in favor of the acquisition were MinnesotaPower/ALLETE employees and labor union members. Their expectations of past andpresent job satisfaction and their trust in future employment under new ownership werereiterated. However, there are no guarantees in two short years that their job satisfaction oreven their employment will continue. Local control over all their employment futures willbe taken away. And losing local control of our public utilities management could haveserious and cascading effects upon our entire region, the LEAST of them being a (probablyguaranteed) rise in electrical rates. I confess: alarm bells go off for me.Various outside experts hired by the MN Department of Commerce and even the office ofthe Attorney General are critical of this acquisition by two huge private companies,particularly GIP. Groups such as Sierra Club, CURE, CUB, individuals and shareholdershave recommended that the Public Utilities Commission reject the deal. Both CPP andGIP's main argument for their acquisition is that ALLETE's goal of net-zero carbonemissions by 2040 can more easily be financially reached with them. But neither partner isforthcoming about their real future goals. MY biggest concern is that in ALLETE beingowned by a private company, who knows what will happen? I have far more trust in public,information-sharing companies who have access to public markets. I would not mindALLETE being in a limited partnership with CPP. (I would like to see us teaming with ourCanadian neighbors.) Iwould prefer ALLETE expand its public shareholder base, ratherthan be absorbed by the biggest profit entity in the world. (I would be willing to buy shares!)Do I trust GIP/BlackRock? No. I don't, frankly. Why do they want to acquire ALLETE? I don'tbelieve their goal is to help Minnesota achieve net-zero carbon emissions. I have beenfollowing this week's stories about the Panama Canal, and BlackRock's CEO, Larry Fink,who is determined to gain control of Panama's main ports. Perhaps BlackRock is moreinterested in the fact that we are a port, than in helping with climate control. Maybe Fink ismore interested in controlling ten percent of the world's fresh water, or gaining mineralrights access. I do not trust this humongous, gobbling entity bent on profit and power.I keep coming back to this: Potential risks to consumers and protectors of our lakes,our lands, our waters, our grandchildren's futures outweigh any potential benefits.Lynn Tryggestad, 4101 Gladstone St., Duluth MN 55804, 218-341-7405Kyan Iryggestad Thenk,eyou

Public Comment for Docket noE015/PA-24-198April 9, 2025To Minnesota Public Utilities CommissionI am a Minnesota Power customer and I care aboutthe integrity and performance of our public utility.I strongly disagree with the acquisition of Allete. It is not in the public interest.ByG E VEAPR 1 4 2025SincerelyShawneen KildeMailaddress P.0, box 1476International Falls, Mn. 546649Home telephone 218-283-4457

content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Steve M
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: PUC Docket Number 24-198
Date: Tuesday, April 22, 2025 9:05:01 AM
You don't often get email from steve_m_2000@hotmail.com. Learn why this is important
To Whom It May Concern:
As former long-time employees of Allete/Minnesota Power, and as retirees who receive both a
pension and medical reimbursement from the company, we are writing to express our strongopposition to the proposed sale of Allete to Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a subsidiaryof Blackrock, and the Canada Pension Plan Fund (CPP).
We are also current shareholders of Allete. However, if this deal is approved, all shareholders
—ourselves included—will be forced to sell our shares. We will have no choice in the matter.That alone is deeply concerning, as it strips away the voice and investment of long-timeemployees, retirees, and individuals who believe in the company’s long-term mission and itsvalue to Minnesota communities.
This $6.2 billion sale is facing well-founded opposition from a diverse coalition of
stakeholders, including consumer advocates, the mining and wood products industries, and theMinnesota Department of Commerce. The concerns are substantial and credible: increasedrates for customers, loss of local control, and a lack of transparency throughout the process.
GIP and CPP argue that they are better positioned to fund Allete’s renewable energy transition
and infrastructure needs. Yet testimony from financial and regulatory experts, including thoserepresenting the Minnesota Department of Commerce, disputes these claims. They cite a lackof evidence that the acquisition would improve access to capital or benefit ratepayers in anymeaningful way. In fact, the proposed transaction appears to pose significant risk of large rateincreases, speculative investment strategies, and an erosion of public oversight.
Furthermore, we are disturbed by reports that GIP and CPP have avoided transparency during
these proceedings—refusing to answer questions fully, providing redacted responses, andlimiting meaningful public engagement. This lack of openness is not compatible with the trustand accountability required of a utility provider responsible for serving Minnesota homes andbusinesses.
Minnesota Power is more than a utility—it’s part of the fabric of the state and the communities
it serves. It should not be turned over to private equity interests with global portfolios andshort-term profit motives. We urge the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission and allinvolved regulatory bodies to reject this acquisition and preserve Allete’s accountability to thepublic.
Steve Maasch

I am a 16 year employee of ALLETE/MP and my home is in their service territory. I support the merger
for a few reasons and write to you after witnessing the Duluth hearing.This is my opinion, not on behalf of the company. The path of merger is the hard path with significant damage to the public and shareholders should itnot be approved. Starting this process puts ALLETE on a path to either succeed in a merger with favorable partners orbe taken over by another entity while vulnerable after failure. Regardless the stock holders would take a hit and the public would not have the benefit of low costaccess to capital. In the end, ALLETE will have to get the money somewhere. If I asked a bank or the stock market for double my net worth the interest rate would be very high. Thesame goes for ALLETE as it plans to meet the goal of green energy. From my perspective it is either merge with the right partner or be taken over by a merger we probablydon’t want negotiating from stock at 30.00 a share vs 67.00 If ALLETE is not successful, its likely that the culture I’ve known and trust will die at the hands of avulture style merger. I support the merger because it is the best chance to save the best company I’ve ever worked for andthe right thing for its customers long term. Chad Lander

In reviewing the information made available I have serious concerns about the consumer
impact of the sale of MN Power. The continued increases in the cost of electricity  havebecome a major concern for us over the last few years.  While there are reasons, some merited,for these increases the impact is still the same:  given that many have no energy sourcealternative choice, if we want/need electrical service we are compelled to purchase it from MNPower.
However, inasmuch as MN Power is more-or-less a "local" company, there is a perceived and
perhaps some well-deserved trust in MN Power's sensitivity to the customer.  With the sale Isee no assurance that sensitivity will continue.  It seems that MN Power would become a place-of-profit division for the purchasers less than a customer-sensitive organisation providing anessential service.
Simply put, no sale is the best option.
-- Bruce PennerLifelong Customer1872 County Road 3Carlton, MN 55718
